data.title: Go to definition with multiple definition shows `peek` but doesn't explain why
data.body:
- execute a go to definition where the symbol has multiple definitions
- the peek experience shows up with all the definitions

This is good, but since I wasn't aware that there are multiple definitions it wasn't obvious to me, why peek shows up and why I don't jump immediately to the definition, see below.

The peek zone should provide a hint in the title `Multiple Definitions Found` that explains why peek shows up.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172399/13598499/5b792e4e-e51e-11e5-9201-fd0744a0f2bf.png)

data.title: Build support
data.body:
_From @JanKok on March 8, 2016 8:36_

I'm trying to do C code development using gcc and make and using WebFreak001's gdb debugger extension. I added `"preLaunchTask": "make"` to launch.json and

```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "make",
    "isShellCommand": false,
    // Show the output window only if unrecognized errors occur.
    "showOutput": "always", //"silent",

    // use the standard tsc problem matcher to find compile problems
    // in the output.
    "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
}
```

in tasks.json and now make runs each time I click start, which is pretty good. But,
1. If there are compile errors (resulting in make returning an error value), Code doesn't stop. It tries to run the program anyway.
2. The make output window appears momentarily but is replaced with the debug console (which BTW displays the cryptic message `undefined=thread-group-added,id="i1"`). I'd like the output window to remain visible if there are make errors.
3. F8, Ctrl-Shift-M etc., don't work to let me visit the errors in my source code. What does it take to make that work?

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-docs#215_

data.title: NLS build has an issue with \' in string
data.body:
- Uncomment asserts on line 370 in /extensions/json/server/src/test/schema.test.ts
- run "gulp watch-build"
- run "./scripts/test.sh --build"
  1) JSON Schema Schema contributions:
      + expected - actual
  
  ```
  -Problems loading reference \'http://myschemastore/myschemafoo\': Unable to load schema from \'http://myschemastore/myschemafoo\': Not Found. The requested location could not be found.
  +Problems loading reference 'http://myschemastore/myschemafoo': Unable to load schema from 'http://myschemastore/myschemafoo': Not Found. The requested location could not be found.
  ```

Problematic string is in jsonSchemaService:
resolveErrors.push(localize('json.schema.problemloadingref', 'Problems loading reference \'{0}\': {1}', loc, unresolvedSchema.errors[0]));

Looking at /home/martinae/workspaces/vscode/extensions/json/server/out/jsonSchemaService.nls.json,
The backslash got escaped as well

 "Problems loading reference \'{0}\': {1}"

data.title: Support for locally installed npm tools
data.body:
This is just an observation based on the Feb release notes. I just thought I'd mention it in case is a general assumption rather than just for ESLint plugin

In a coupe of places the release notes for Eslint make the assumption that it will be globally installed. I have found global installation to be an anti-pattern and now install all dev deps locally for each project. The reason is version clashes. It is possible to be working on a project that requires specific version of such tools. This is likely of you switch often. Also I use nvm-winodws for different version of node which doesn't share global installations. Also local installation means package.json much better describes the dependencies.

It's easy to run any local tool by prefixing it with ./node_modules./bin/ or better, add a npm script which add that to the path when run.

In general code and plugins should support everything installed locally.

I've not yet hopped on my dev pc to see if the new release works with my local ESLint installation and config.

thanks for listening

data.title: Changing language mode in diff view does not persist the mode for the file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
1. Create two new files test1, test2
2. Compare them and change the mode of those files in the diff view, for example to `javascript`
3. The mode nicely changes for both files in the diff view
4. However, I would expect that when I open those files in a regular view the `javascript` mode is persisted. It is not, only one of those files has `javascript`, the other still has `plain text`

Related to #2932

data.title: TypeScript debug - spaces in path
data.body:
Hello guys!

Some days ago I was trying to debug a Node.js application written in TypeScript from Visual Studio Code and I had some troubles; then I asked on [stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/35606423/visual-studio-code-debug-node-js-through-typescript) and shared my code on [GitHub](https://github.com/7brutus7/stackoverflow).
This is the latest working version, you can download it and **debug** correctly on Visual Studio Code (by "debug correctly" I mean that you can add a breakpoint on a .ts file and then see the debugger stopping on it) but if you then rename the **root folder** by adding some **spaces in the path** (for example changing from "stackoverflow" to "stack overflow") the debugger stops working and when launching it I get the following **error**:

`Cannot launch program 'c:\Users\brutus\Desktop\stack overflow\src\app.ts'; setting the 'outDir' attribute might help.`

I think it's a **bug** but I'm not completely sure, can you confirm please?

Thank you very much, hope this helps! :smile:

data.body:
In the [EditorConfig](https://github.com/editorconfig/editorconfig-vscode) plugin, we want to implement `end_of_line` as well. In the latest VS Code release, I noticed that we have a `files.eol` setting now. Would it be possible to expose this to the `TextEditorOptions` interface to set this on the fly?

// @alexandrudima

data.title: Task with forward slashes, isShellCommand and in Windows fails to execute
data.body:
Only happens in Windows.

I have the file `folder/hello.cmd` in my workspace. When I setup the following task I always get the same error:

```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "./folder/hello",
    "isShellCommand": true,
...
```

```
'.' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
```

It appears that Code is launching a command named `.`.

When I surround the command with quotes it works:

```
    "command": "\"./folder/hello\""
```

What is happening is that due to `isShellCommand`, `cmd.exe` is the spawned process. Now, `cmd.exe`'s optional arguments always start with forward slashes, so it seems to incorrectly assume that `/folder` and `/hello` are options, leaving the `.` to be the command to execute.

data.title: Some common keyboard shortcuts key are not supported
data.body:
Repro:
I noticed that most of the common debugging scenarios like F5, F10, F11, Shift+F11, Shift+F5 have all supported in VSCode, however, some of common shortcuts key are not support yet.
1. Currently "Run to cursor" only support from context menu, keyboard shortcuts key "Ctrl+F10" hasn't been supported yet,  it would be great if we can add this support as it also uses very frequently during debugging. 
2. Do we plan to add support for "Start without debugging" and the relevant keyboard shortcut key  "Ctrl+F5" ?

2.  Manually move the mouse to select these contents, and then right click to select "Copy Value" and paste into a text file,  only following contents can be copied into the test file. seems that the "Copy Value" can only copy the value of the variables, however, when I try to use it to copy the output sting, it can only copy a part of output string ? It is not a good experience here.

data.title: Detecting TS file as JavsScript when shebang exists
Folding is whitespace sensitive
0.10.10 erroring on object spread properties in .js files
data.body:
… and I can't turn it off by setting `javascript.validate.enable` false. 

Perhaps this is a soft documentation bug: the [release notes](https://code.visualstudio.com/Updates) proudly mention `experimentalObjectRestSpread` but then say:

> Support for ObjectRestSpread is not yet provided by Salsa but it is on the roadmap (see Microsoft/TypeScript#2103).

… which is confusing and misleading.

It's confusing because the stand-out tone of core dev responses to that issue is "not until TC39 moves it to stage 3; bother them, not us", which is much less optimistic than the Feb 2016 release notes or the [TypeScript Roadmap](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/Roadmap) itself.

It's misleading because it fails to **describe the impact** of "support… not yet provided" as **error messages you can't make go away**. If there's some way to make them go away, please describe it in that part of the release notes. If not, I don't think it's too strong to outright **advise users of object spread properties to delay upgrading**.

Without a work-around, this kills `code` for me, as I now have to dig for the real errors amongst a few dozen erroneous:
- `Property assignment expected.`
- `Argument expression expected.`
- `Declaration or statement expected.`

I trust a workaround is possible, as `code` is not erroring in JSX.

data.title: Distinguish code area from glyph area
data.body:
This is small issue for me.

Code folding is very great useful.
But it made margin between line numbers and first character in each line.
When I use "2 spaces indent", that margin looks like indent.
Now, I use `editor.rulers` setting includes `0` like `[0, 100, 120]` to indicate a start point of a line. But it is not pretty.

Is this issue solved by any theme?
I think that it is solved by just a little changing a color of the left side area of first character in each line.

data.title: IntelliSense with types of JSDoc
data.body:
I tried this:

``` js

/**
 * @param {string} param1 - Normal
 * @param {string|number|boolean} param2 - Multiple types
 * @param {null} param3 - (I know this is strange param.)
 * @param {string|number|null} param4 - Multiple types includes `null`
 * @param {Object} param5 - Object type
 * @param {Array} param6 - Array type
 * @param {jQuery} param7 - Another type
 * @param {MyClass} param8 - Another type
 * @param {string|number|Array} param9 - Multiple types includes `Array`
 * @param {?string} param10 - Nullable type
 * @param {string} [param11] - Optional
 * @returns {?string} result
 */
function fnc(param1, param2, param3, param4, param5, param6,
    param7, param8, param9, param10, param11) {
  return param11;
}

fnc();
```
- param3: any, param4: any, param6: any, param7: any, param8: any, param9: any
- param10: string

It seems that:
- The type of `@param` that includes `null`, `Array`, and other classes other than `Object` are shown as `any`.
- The optional params are shown with `?`, but nullable params and returns are shown with nothing.

I hope that the specified types are shown even if that is `null`, `Array`, or unknown type such as `jQuery` or `MyClass`. And nullable params are shown like optional params.

data.title: Option to disable file explorer jump to current file.
data.body:
At the moment, whenever you focus one of the editors, the file explorer jumps to the location of said file, however, it should stay wherever I left it last. Run case:

1) Open a file in editor 1.
2) Open a file in editor 2.
3) Navigate to new file in explorer.
4) Realize I want to open it in editor 1.
5) Focus editor 1.
6) File explorer jumped to editor 1's file.
7) Navigate _again_ to my new file.
8) Open new file.

if there's a way to do this already I'm all ears, I've look through the doc and shortcuts, couldn't find anything.
